persona.name: Raúl Enrique Velázquez Cruz

occupation.title: Owner / Operator of neighborhood 'tiendita' (convenience grocery)
occupation.organization: Velázquez Tienda de la Esquina (self-run, sole proprietorship, informal bookkeeping)
occupation.description: Raúl runs a small, family-oriented convenience store in a middle-class suburban colonia of Zapopan. He opens early, sources products from a mix of wholesalers and local distributors, negotiates credit with a nearby abarrotes supplier, and manages day-to-day operations including stocking, pricing, customer service, and simple bookkeeping. Responsibilities include cash handling, ordering, rotating perishables (bread, dairy), preparing a small selection of ready-to-eat items (tortas, tamales on certain days), supervising one part-time helper (his nephew on weekends), and dealing with municipal inspectors. He balances formal receipts with a majority of cash transactions. He knows how to read supplier invoices, keep a daily cash journal, and file basic tax paperwork when necessary, but he prefers to remain small rather than scale rapidly. He sometimes does occasional catering or supplies beverages to a local fonda and helps neighbors with small delivery runs using his motorcycle.
skills_used: Basic bookkeeping and daily cash reconciliation
Negotiation with suppliers and credit management
Customer service and community relationship management
Basic food preparation and hygiene for on-site snacks
Simple promotional tactics (phone broadcasts, price specials)
Problem solving under uncertainty (short supply, price changes)
occupation.work_hours: Typically 7:00 AM to 8:30 PM most weekdays, shorter hours Sundays; shares some tasks with his wife and family for big events.

persona.education: Completed preparatoria (high school). Later took a two-semester technical course in bookkeeping and small-business administration at a local Centro de Capacitación para el Trabajo (CECATI). Attended evening workshops on inventory control and basic food handling offered by the municipal commerce office; informal mentoring from an older relative who ran a tienda.
long_term_goals: Provide stable education for his two children so at least one can finish university or a professional technical degree.
Expand the neighborhood tienda into a small esquina grocery with a refrigerated section and a moto delivery service.
Buy a newer family car (reliable compact van) and pay off the small debts within five years.
Own a modest single-story house free of mortgage within 10-12 years or refinance to lower monthly payments.
Have predictable health care access (stable Imss/Seguro Popular coverage for the family) and save for retirement/funerary costs so his wife is not burdened.
Be seen as a steady, respected member of the colonia — someone neighbors can rely on.
Take his family on a short vacation to the coast (Puerto Vallarta or Colima) at least once.
Pass the tienda to one of his children as a viable livelihood if they want it.
Learn some basic digital marketing to keep the shop relevant (online presence for orders via WhatsApp).
Reduce monthly stress by building a small emergency fund equal to three months of expenses.

style.verbal_style: Speaks Spanish with a Jaliscan regional accent (noticeable cadence and occasional localisms such as 'órale', 'qué onda', 'compa', 'ahí va'). Polite and affable with customers: uses diminutives ('¿Quiere una tostadita?'), teases familiar clients gently, and is deferential with elders. When speaking with officials or suppliers he becomes more formal and measured. Uses short storytelling to make a point — beginning with 'Mire, le cuento...' and often ending anecdotes with a laugh or an exasperated '¡Así es la vida!'.
style.nonverbal_mannerisms: Talks with his hands when excited or describing quantities; leans forward when listening; tilts head and raises eyebrows when skeptical; often wipes hands on apron when thinking. Laughs with a low chuckle and claps once to punctuate a joke. Keeps eye contact but respectfully looks away when embarrassed.
style.digital_communication: Prefers WhatsApp for business and family messaging — sends voice notes when in a rush and short text messages for orders. Rarely posts on Facebook but checks family groups; uses YouTube for tutorials and soccer highlights. When writing, he is concise, uses emojis sparingly (thumbs up, smiling face), and tends to use colloquial phrases.
style.presentation: Dresses practically: short-sleeve polos or work shirts, sturdy jeans, rubber-soled shoes, and an apron during shop hours. Keeps a ballpoint pen behind his ear. On Sundays dresses a bit nicer for church and family visits (collared shirt, better shoes).
style.conflict_style: Low-key and conciliatory by default: tries to defuse conflict with humor or small concessions. If pressured or lied to (e.g., by a supplier), becomes firm and refuses repeat business. Trust is transactional: quick to forgive minor slights but slow to trust again on financial matters.

traits: Family-first: organizes life around children's schedules and extended-family gatherings.
Pragmatic: focuses on practical, immediate solutions rather than abstract theory.
Warm and sociable: enjoys casual conversations with customers and neighbors.
Cautious with money: frugal and methodical about expenses; keeps mental lists.
Agreeable and community-minded: helps neighbors in small ways, volunteers at local posadas.
Resilient: bounces back from setbacks like a slow week or a theft.
Stubborn on principles: will not compromise on honesty even when pressured.
Anxious about finances: occasionally loses sleep over bills and credit payments.
Optimistic but realistic: believes things will improve with effort, but plans for setbacks.
Conscientious about work: arrives early, checks shelves and cash till every day.
Modestly prideful: takes pride in the cleanliness of his tienda and in being a dependable host at family events.
Traditional in some values (religion, gender roles at times) but tolerant and practical.

openness.notes: Open to practical new ideas (mobile orders via WhatsApp, simple packaging) but skeptical of fads or abstract ideologies.

conscientiousness.notes: Very organized in daily operations, reliable, keeps routines and records for his shop and family finances.

extraversion.notes: Energized by interacting with customers and neighbors, enjoys social gatherings and local soccer matches.

agreeableness.notes: Cooperative, helpful, community-minded; values harmony and will often give familiar customers a small discount in hard times.

neuroticism.notes: Worries about money and health; experiences periodic stress and irritability under financial pressure, but generally maintains steady functioning.

interests: Family gatherings and multi-generational meals (Sunday comida with mother and grandparents when possible).
Watching Liga MX soccer (follows C.D. Guadalajara / Chivas closely).
Telenovelas and light dramas in the evenings (keeps up with one or two current series).
Short local trips to the coast (Puerto Vallarta) and mountain towns in Jalisco.
Radio news in the morning and local community broadcasts.
Learning small-business tips on YouTube (inventory management, simple marketing).
Fixing small household items (practical DIY projects).
Attending the church on special dates and participating in parish fundraisers.
Helping at school events (aguinaldo collection, venta de tortas).
Trying new snack products that sell well in the tienda (chips, candies, bottled drinks).
Listening to regional Mexican music: banda, mariachi, and occasionally norteño.
Football matches with friends at the tienda or at a local fonda on weekends.
Watching streamed shows on Netflix occasionally (crime dramas, soccer documentaries).
Participating in the colonia's WhatsApp group to coordinate neighborhood matters.
Collecting small savings jars for the children's education fund.
Comparing prices across wholesalers to keep margins.
Using smartphone apps for simple accounting templates.
Sampling different local atole/antojitos and selling successful items in the shop.
Following weather forecasts to plan purchases of water and soft drinks for hot days.
Observing competitors' prices to keep his tienda competitive.
likes: Tacos al pastor from the stand two blocks away.
Fresh bolillos and hot tamales delivered early in the morning.
Drinking café de olla on cold mornings at home.
Sharing beer (Jarritos or a light local brand) with neighbors after a long day.
Sales and promotions from wholesalers (bulk deals).
Seeing regular customers return and bring friends.
Simple, clean packaging and easy-to-prepare snack items.
Small luxuries for the family on payday (ice cream, a movie outing).
Attending and hosting posadas at Christmas.
Buying children's school supplies before the new school year.
Watching Chivas matches with a group of neighbors.
Using WhatsApp voice notes for quick, friendly messages.
Local markets (tianguis) for occasional better deals on produce.
Practical gifts (work boots for his nephew, a new blender for the house).
Public holidays for extra sales (Día de Muertos, Mother's Day).
Friendly haggling with small suppliers — enjoys the back-and-forth.
Maintaining a tidy storefront and a small display that attracts customers.
Short, inexpensive family excursions on long weekends.
Creating a small loyalty habit: 'la tercera ya lleva descuento' informal practice.
Receiving praise from his wife when the books balance at the end of the month.
dislikes: Theft, whether petty or organized, and the anxiety it causes.
Corruption among local officials or suppliers who inflate invoices.
Being ignored by customers when asking politely to pay or return change.
Large deliveries that arrive late or damaged.
Long bureaucratic processes at municipal offices.
Harsh criticism of his parenting choices from outsiders.
Being forced to close early due to neighborhood problems.
Expensive, unnecessary gadgets that complicate daily work.
People who don't respect queue order or line etiquette at the shop.
Fake or low-quality branded products that damage trust.
Having to go to the bank in person for long waits (prefers small cash handling).
Gossip that harms someone's reputation in the colonia.
Excessive noise late at night near the shop that scares customers away.
Inflation that erodes savings and purchasing power.

tv_and_streaming: Telenovelas on free-to-air TV after dinner.
YouTube channels for DIY repairs, simple accounting tips, and quick recipes.
Local radio in the mornings for traffic, weather, and soccer results.
Occasional Facebook videos shared by family — watches, rarely comments.
favorite_shows_and_media: Local sports radio and highlight shows for Liga MX.
A favored soap opera that airs in the evening (follows main plotlines).
YouTube tutorials titled 'Cómo llevar una tiendita' and 'Menús rápidos para vender'.
Documentaries about football or regional history when available.

food_and_drink_preferences: Breakfast: bolillo with refried beans or eggs, sometimes café de olla.
Lunch: hearty plates (arroz, frijoles, guisado) eaten with family at noon.
Snacks sold in the tienda: popular chips, dulces, bottled aguas frescas.
Drinks: prefers Coca-Cola or Jarritos for customers; drinks light beer socially.
Favorite treats: flan casero, carnitas tortas on Sundays.
Coffee preference: café de olla at home; instant coffee in a pinch during busy shifts.
Spicy foods: enjoys salsa roja or serrano on tacos but avoids extreme heat when with children.
Purchasing habits: buys produce fresh daily from tianguis; staples in bulk from wholesalers.
shopping_habits_and_brands: Buys wholesale staples at a local distribuidora and smaller, perishable items at the tianguis.
Visits Bodega Aurrera or Chedraui occasionally for non-food items and larger discounts.
Uses Telcel for mobile service; pays prepaid plans and recharges regularly.
Prefers flexible suppliers that offer short-term credit after trust is built.
Looks for brands that customers recognize and trust; tentative about new generic brands unless trial sales go well.
Avoids long-term contracts unless the return is clear (e.g., refrigeration with low instalment cost).

beliefs: The government should guarantee access to basic healthcare for everyone — public clinics and Imss are important.
Small businesses are the backbone of local neighborhoods and deserve easier access to credit.
Education is the surest path for his children to have better opportunities.
Hard work and honesty are virtues that will pay off over time.
Politicians often say the right things but many are corrupt; you need to judge them by actions.
PRI historically provided programs that helped small businesses in his parents' time; he's sympathetic to that record.
Taxes must be fair — he accepts paying them but dislikes opaque fees.
Public safety is crucial: more police presence and community surveillance would reduce theft.
Government should invest in local infrastructure (street lighting, potable water, better pavements).
Community networks (neighbors, church, relatives) are the real social safety net.
Religion (Catholicism) provides moral guidance and important social rituals, though he is not fanatical.
Family obligations often come before individual desires; caring for elders is a duty.
Women should have the right to work and study; his wife contributes substantially to household management and the business.
Youth need alternatives to crime: sports, training programs, and apprenticeships are effective.
Corruption at the municipal level is a major everyday problem for small entrepreneurs.
The market should allow private initiative but the state must step in to protect the most vulnerable.
He supports targeted subsidies for basic food items in times of crisis, but not blanket handouts that create dependency.
Foreign investment is okay if it respects local suppliers and doesn't displace small shops.
Health prevention (vaccination, screenings) is practical and necessary; he took his children to vaccinations as scheduled.
Public schools should improve infrastructure and teacher training; parents should be involved in school committees.
Trust in strangers is low; business relationships are built slowly through reputation.
Debt is useful if managed; short-term microcredit can help growth but must be used cautiously.
He believes in saving a small amount regularly — a jar for emergencies and an account for longer goals.
Technology is a useful tool (smartphones, WhatsApp) but can be distracting and sometimes wastes time.
Media often exaggerates: he prefers to hear local accounts and verify before forming an opinion.
Small rituals (Sunday mass, birthday gatherings) keep family ties strong and provide psychological relief.
Public health systems must be strengthened rather than replaced by expensive private options.
Local festivals maintain cultural identity and are worth supporting with small donations or time.
The police should be accountable; communities should work with honest officers rather than assume all are bad.
Climate change is visible in irregular rainy seasons and hotter summers; he supports municipal tree-planting and better drainage but is not an activist.
Immigrants working abroad are often forced by circumstance — families benefit from remittances but social costs exist.
Same-sex neighbors should be treated respectfully — he believes in decency and wants peace in the colonia even if his views are shaped by tradition.
The best leaders are those who listen to everyday people and prioritize public services over flashy projects.
A stable price of staples is more important than luxury investments by the state.
Family honor matters — promises should be kept and debts repaid if possible.
Local businesses should coordinate to resist criminal extortion and to lobby for safer streets.
skills: Daily bookkeeping: records sales, expenses, and daily cash reconciliation in a small ledger.
Supplier negotiation: secures short-term credit and negotiates bulk discounts.
Customer service: reads customers' moods, offers small free samples when useful, and retains regulars.
Basic food preparation: makes tortas, heats tamales, prepares aguas frescas and simple snacks.
Inventory management: rotates goods, manages expiration dates, orders in time to avoid stockouts.
Simple maintenance: fixes shelving, replaces light bulbs, basic plumbing patch-ups.
Motorcycle driving and safe, short-distance delivery handling.
Smartphone-savvy for business: WhatsApp orders, price checking, sending voice notes and pictures for bulk orders.
Budgeting and informal financial planning: allocates payroll, groceries, and a small savings jar.
Conflict resolution within the community: mediates small disputes between neighbors or customers.
Basic Spanish literacy (reading supplier invoices, municipal notices); basic numeracy for change and totals.
Sales forecasting by experience: knows which items sell more depending on weather and school calendar.

general: Greets regulars by name and often asks about family members — strong memory for faces and relationships.
Keeps a small cash float separated from business takings to handle immediate small expenses.
Leans on family members for large shop tasks; shares responsibilities with wife during peak hours.
Offers credit to trusted neighbors in small amounts with informal IOUs.
Calls his brother or cousin when a supplier issue arises or to borrow a tool.
Quick to volunteer for parish or colonia events (posadas, charity sales) as part of community reciprocity.
Checks prices weekly and adjusts small price stickers if wholesale costs change.
Avoids loud fights in public — acts as peacemaker or dissuasion agent.
Uses short afternoon breaks to nap briefly or listen to a radio program.
Keeps one hand free to open the shop gate quickly when customers arrive.

morning: Wakes around 5:30–6:00 AM; drinks café de olla; reviews the day's list.
Picks up fresh bolillos and tamales from the local bakery before opening.
Opens the shop by 7:00 AM, arranges the front display, and turns on the radio.
Checks WhatsApp messages for orders and supplier confirmations.
Counts cash from the previous day and records in ledger.
workday: Greets customers, prepares simple snacks at mid-morning, and refills shelves from back stock.
Takes a short lunch (shared family meal around 1:00 PM) then returns to the shop.
Handles deliveries from wholesalers in the late afternoon; reconciles invoices.
Teaches his nephew simple tasks and inspects the shop's cleanliness before evening rush.
Closes registers, locks the shop gate, and tallies the day's takings before heading home.
evening: Attends occasional evening parish meetings or neighborhood association sessions.
Watches soccer or a telenovela with the family; shares a beer with his wife on payday.
Checks children's homework briefly and discusses school matters.
Makes a voice note to suppliers for next-day orders before bed.
Goes to sleep around 11:00 PM, sometimes later if balancing books.
weekend: Opens later on Sundays and dedicates more time to family: church in the morning, comida at noon.
Participates in local matches or watches games with neighbors at a fonda.
Does the week's larger purchases at the distribuidora or mercado on Saturdays.
Helps with school sales or community events; lends the tienda for charity collection points.

health.general_health: Generally functional but not athletic. A bit overweight (approx. BMI in the overweight range), with family history of type 2 diabetes (mother).
specific_conditions: Borderline high blood pressure (measures occasionally elevated during stressful months).
Pre-diabetic indicators in recent routine screening (fasting glucose slightly above normal).
Mild lower-back pain from long hours standing and lifting boxes.
Occasional heartburn related to late meals and fried foods.
Minor dental issues (one filling), tends to postpone dental visits due to cost.
medications_and_care: Uses over-the-counter analgesics for headaches or back pain; sometimes takes antihypertensive prescribed intermittently but adherence is inconsistent when finances are tight.
Visits municipal health clinic for basic vaccines and check-ups when possible.
Children are up to date with vaccinations; family uses public health services for routine care.
lifestyle: Diet: heavy on tortillas, rice, beans, occasional fried food; tries to include fruits when affordable.
Exercise: low structured exercise — walks occasionally, helps with physical tasks at the shop.
Sleep: 6–7 hours typical but can fall to 4–5 hours during stressful periods.
Alcohol and tobacco: drinks socially (1–2 beers) on weekends; non-smoker but sometimes around smokers.
Mental health: experiences situational anxiety about finances, manages through prayer, family support, and small rituals (praying before opening the shop).
health.access_to_care: Uses IMSS or municipal health clinics for primary care and children's services. Supports public healthcare expansion to improve access and reduce costs.

relationships.name: María Araceli Cruz (wife)
relationships.description: Cohabitating wife who helps with the tienda in afternoons and Sundays. Practical, detail-oriented, handles household finances together with Raúl. They have a stable but sometimes tense relationship when money is tight; deep mutual respect and shared parenting duties.

relationships.name: Diego Velázquez (son)
relationships.description: Son in secundaria (middle school). Likes soccer and helps with errands at the shop after school; promising student but sometimes distracted by friends.

relationships.name: Sofía Velázquez (daughter)
relationships.description: Daughter in primaria (elementary). Cheerful, helps arrange candy shelves playfully; Raúl is protective and invests in her school supplies.

relationships.name: Doña Carmen Cruz (mother-in-law)
relationships.description: Lives nearby; provides occasional babysitting and is a respected voice in family matters. Traditional, attends church frequently.

relationships.name: Héctor Velázquez (brother)
relationships.description: Older brother who runs a small carpentry shop; trades favors (repairs, help moving bulk stock); trusted confidant on business decisions.

relationships.name: Carlos (nephew)
relationships.description: Works weekends at the tienda; learning the ropes and being mentored by Raúl.

relationships.name: Local parish priest (Padre Miguel)
relationships.description: Respected by Raúl, they coordinate parish activities and charity posadas where Raúl volunteers the tienda as a donation point.

relationships.name: Grupo de vecinos (colonia WhatsApp group)
relationships.description: Active group used to coordinate safety, market days, and small favors. Raúl posts announcements about store hours, special offers, and school supply collections.

relationships.name: Regular customers (various)
relationships.description: A network of about 20–30 regular households who depend on Raúl's tienda daily for staples; relationships are mutually supportive and sometimes blur personal and commercial lines.

relationships.name: Supplier contacts (distribuidora manager, 'Don Luis')
relationships.description: Key supplier with whom Raúl has negotiated a credit line; maintains cautious but cordial relations.

other_facts: Born in a mid-sized city in Jalisco and moved to Zapopan as a child; most of his extended family still lives in the region.
Grew up helping his parents in their small tienda, learned to count change before he could ride a bike.
Was the first in his immediate family to finish preparatoria and attended night classes to study bookkeeping.
Met his wife María at a local church youth event; they have been together for 20 years and married for 16.
Has two children, Diego (14) and Sofía (9), and is very proud when they do well in school.
His father was a small tradesman who taught him to fix shelves and treat customers with respect.
Once had a week-long supply shortage when a distributor forgot his order — learned to maintain a two-day buffer of staples after that.
Experienced a small burglary five years ago; lost some cash and learned to improve his lock and install a basic CCTV camera (still somewhat mistrustful of the system's reliability).
Keeps a small 'alcancía' jar at home for emergencies and another separate one for holiday expenses.
Has a modest motorcycle (Honda or similar) used for short deliveries and errands; dreams of upgrading to a compact van.
Pays careful attention to municipal announcements because street fairs can boost sales significantly.
Is known in his colonia for arranging last-minute purchases for neighbors in need, sometimes allowing delayed payment.
Participated in a local entrepreneurship training promoted by the municipality and received a small starter kit for refrigeration once (a refrigerator on low-interest instalments).
Has a set phrase he often uses: 'Con que Dios y trabajo, sale el día,' which he says when closing the shop.
Enjoys telling neighborhood jokes and short stories about his childhood; uses humor to defuse tension.
Once organized a small fundraiser at the tienda for a neighbor's medical bills; coordinated a rota of contributions across regular customers.
Saves receipts in a cardboard box organized by month; occasionally gets advice from a cousin on tax filing.
His favorite tequila brand is a modest one from Jalisco used only in celebrations; otherwise prefers beer socially.
Has a worn-out apron with a small pen pocket that he considers a practical 'good luck' charm.
Keeps a small notebook under the counter with scribbled phone numbers, supplier contacts, and a record of informal IOUs for trusted clients.
Has been approached once by a microfinance representative; turned down a loan because the repayment schedule was too tight.
Participates in local posadas every December and coordinates a small sugar-candy and pan dulce promotion for customers.
Sometimes helps Diego practice penalty kicks in the nearby cancha; has a group of fathers who organize friendly matches.
Attends mass on important dates (First Communions, Christmas, Good Friday) and contributes small donations to the church for community events.
Remembers his grandmother's mole recipe and occasionally cooks a simplified version for special family occasions.
Has a small scar on his left hand from a childhood accident with a knife; tells the story to kids who ask about it.
Learned basic Excel skills during a short municipal course but mostly uses a paper ledger; hopes to improve digital record keeping.
He is mildly superstitious about certain things: never opens umbrellas inside the shop and believes in small rituals before big purchases.
Had an early mentor, Don Raúl (no relation), who advised him to keep margins low but reliable and to always honor community trust.
Once took a short trip to Guadalajara's historic center with his wife and remembers the mariachi and the cathedral as a romantic memory.
He contributed small amounts to his children's school party funds and helped organize a raffle once to buy classroom materials.
Was briefly a member of the colonia security committee and helped negotiate better street lighting with municipal officials.
Keeps an old radio that sometimes picks up soccer commentary better than his phone; the sound quality is part of the shop's atmosphere.
Has a favorite saying from his mother: 'El cliente siempre tiene la razón... hasta que prueba lo contrario' — he uses this to justify customer kindness but sets limits.
Once sold out of a popular candy during Día de Reyes and still gets teased about it by customers — now always stocks an extra box for that holiday demand.
Has a cousin who emigrated to the U.S.; they exchange remittance advice and family news occasionally.
Kept a promise to a former customer by helping her send a package to her son in another state; the reciprocity strengthened community bonds.
Has a small collection of soccer scarves and a framed photograph of his family at a child's First Communion on the tienda wall.
Feels proud when a formerly shy regular customer opens a small business on another corner — he sees it as a sign his community is resilient.
Is cautious about social media: refuses to post intimate family matters but sometimes shares photos of shop promotions in the colonia WhatsApp group.
Has a minor superstition of checking the door three times before sleeping if there's been a disturbance in the colonia that night.
Keeps two extra chairs outside the shop to encourage neighbors to sit, chat, and maybe buy a soda — believes the social aspect drives sales.
Was once asked to give testimony at a minor municipal hearing about commerce hours; prepared notes and delivered a concise, respectful account.
Remembers learning to read supplier invoices with his aunt; considers those lessons foundational to keeping the business afloat.
Has a dream of one day teaching his son Diego how to manage the tienda properly while allowing him to pursue his studies.
